reviewText:
Dark Echo is an evocative piece of art with one of the most brilliant sound designs seen in videogame history. That uses stealth and survival horror conventions to materialize the fears living in our subconscious through abstract and geometrical shapes inspired by the paintings of Rothko
«It’s always night, or we wouldn’t need light» - Theloniuos Monk
Do you remember the first time when you played Super Mario Bros 3? And while you were running through a prolonged and almost infinite hill, pushing the jump button you realized that now Mario could fly. And then, you were amazed with this magic sense of discovery while you explore a vastness sea of pixelated clouds. Creating the magic illusion of exploring a new world in which every single element is full of novelty, an explosion of the senses.

Our gaming memories are full of this accomplished moments of realization. Like the first enemy that you glitch in Axiom Verge. The first kiss you give in Yoshirou Kimura’s cult classic Chulip. Or when you rewinded the time in Braid to reach an unattainable floating plattform for the first time.

Dark Echo has one of these memorable and most captivating single moments experienced in recent videogames. In the form of the first time that you keep pushed the action button, and releasing it you can see how an explosion of visible and corporeal sound waves helps to materialize a previously occult and cryptic hidden dimension. With a plethora of abstract and evocative geometrical forms dazzling our eyes with pure joy. An intense array of emotions are concentrated in this mere act of pushing a single button. As an expression of why the videogames are considered art.

In its first hours, this magic sense of realization never ceases. An absorbing sensation that creates an oppressive feeling in the player, while he’s surrounded by invisible menaces laying in the shadows. An universe where the most feared ghosts plaguing our subconscious are waiting for us surrounded by darkness. Waiting to become corporeal with the mere stimulus of a sound.

We can only figure the world that lies beneath Dark Echo via the materialization of sounds, this fragmented instant of time when a a wave elongates making tangible a mysterious and almost cryptic alternative reality that lives isolated in a corner of our memories, close to our childhood traumas. Playing Dark Echo is like doing a unconscious journey through our fears and hopes, only using our imagination in a synesthetic way, associating sounds and its geometrical effects with inner terrors. And all of these sound elements are augmented by one of the most cohesive artistic designs seen in a videogame, clearly influenced by the paintings of Rothko in its constant use of the black and red colors.

Its level structure is not so distant of a stealth game, where we need to generate geometrical forms thorough sounds to confuse our captors. With a perfect difficulty curve that adds new elements and functions at a very slow pace. The 20 first levels serves as a tutorial, and from 20 onwards, you should prepare to die a lot. It’s like an even more minimalist approach to the VR missions seen in the first Metal Gear Solid. Also, Dark Echo shows its smart design nature by using the name of each level as an evocative clue to resolve its main obstacle. A demonstration of the love and care that its creators have put in the development process.

Maybe Dark Echo can be seen as a small game. But it’s a game in which every single element has been created with an ambitious and creative approach. A short but extremely polished experience that tries to not saturate the player with irrelevant content. Over the years and with the consequent saturation of the gaming market, I appreciate games that really try to be small but memorable journeys. Significative creations in gaming history that we will never forget.

Note that Dark Echo isn’t the first experiment created in the videogame medium to recreate the experience of being a blind person. Previously, the japanese punk videogame designer idol Kenji Eno created Real Sound: Kaze no Regret for Sega Saturn. A game that was designed with blind people in mind, using only sounds and with not a single image. In his next game, Kenji Eno will use the sound as a design fundamental again, with the release of Enemy Zero. A survival horror with invisible enemies, that only can be detected by using a sound radar.

Sadly, Kenji Eno passed away in 2013. But I’m sure that if he lived today, he would become fascinated with Dark Echo.


( The writer of this review is not an English native. So you should expect occasional grammar errors. I apologize in advance. )

It is said that if you want to create a good horror game you depend on three basic factors:

-Sound

-Darkness

-Unknown/mysterious foes

The player's imagination will do the rest.

...

For me, this game nails all these concepts, creating a really immersive and terrifying experience with very basic art & mechanics.

100% recommendable.

reviewText:
I played this a few months ago when it was released on iOS. Great game on both platforms, but playing it on a larger screen definitely adds to the horror factor.

It reminds me of Amnesia: The Dark Descent, especially during the segments where you're being chased through the water as each footstep you take gives away your location to the monsters.

For only $2.00, it's pretty difficult to justify passing it up. If you like horror games, you can't go wrong with Dark Echo. And definitely play it with headphones on. The sound design is incredible.

reviewText:
I want to like this game but I don't find its ambiance or gameplay engaging at all. It feels like a flash or mobile game in the sense that each level is a short path to victory with a tiny variation on the same theme. This is not a bad thing in and of itself but a game that relies on atmosphere should not present you with a transparent series of easy puzzles and little else.

I appreciate the game's clever design but I don't enjoy the gameplay. It didn't feel particularly scary, either: Red blobs make spooky ghost sounds and if you touch them they will eat you and restart the level. That is the sum of this game's horror elements. They will chase you if they hear you but they are stupendously easy to avoid. Holding shift makes you invisible to them and you can throw rocks to draw their attention away from you on a whim.

Some of the levels make interesting use of the game's premise but most felt tedious.

What I liked:
Clever concept, some levels were intriguing, perceiving your environment requires effort

What I didn't like:
Lack of tension, mobile game level design, one-note enemies, lack of meaningful variation

reviewText: Inventive and simple gameplay takes precedence over graphics.  Don't be put off by it's simple execution or think this may not be your type of game until you at least try it.  I found it engaging, fun and (dare I say) somewhat dramatic?  Think echo-location from the movement/sound of your footsteps to provide you with a limited visual slice of the immediate surroundings.  Sometimes you'll find doors, othertimes you'll be chased by a swarm of deadly red hate - and that's when my pulse started to quicken, but all you have to really do (insert evil laugh) is find the exit. Creative, unique and minimalist are the words that immediately come to mind.  I used to have old school 'Tetris' dreams of imagining pieces falling in my sleep when I'd played way too much.  Fast forwad to today and I can imagine this game causing the same type of dreams, ones of walking around in the dark just hoping to find an exit (while red stickly shapes are at my heels)

reviewText:
Just a brief history. Dark Echo is a brilliant mobile game that managed it's way to Steam. The game is minimalistic at best and was created in a short 48 hours for Ludum Dare's Minimalism Contest eventually placing second place. Out of 1600 entries. This is a much more refined and improved version.

This game creates horror and suspense, being one of the most creepy games I've played so far, all while retaining it's simplicity.

The game starts  out by placing you in the footsteps of a blind person alone in the dark. It doesn't give you a clue where you are, what do you encounter and who are you. It is all up to your imagination.

See those red lines chasing you? You don't know who they are. Could be a monster, a zombie or maybe even a serial killer. It is all up to your imagination to find out.

The only clue left is the game's engaging soundtrack - dripping water, doors, creaking bridges, the growling of monsters - it all provides an engaging experience and feel to the game when you play it with headphones, which is recommended by the developers.

If you're one of those who get this through the App Store, I'd recommend getting this through Steam and consider $10 a non-optional donation; They deserve it.

reviewText:
Here is my 30Second Game Review on Dark echo: https://youtu.be/PjP5htKzZ10

This game is like being Daredevil in a psychological thriller. Sound is your only friend. Every noise you make bounces off the wall, making you “see” a minimalistic impression of your surroundings. The effects - mesmerizing.

But you are not alone. You have to escape unknown creatures through mazes and puzzles. And when you make a noise, they notice you as well. So find a safe path, unlock doors and escape death.

Play it with headphones on and all alone in the dark and every step will be filled with tension.

Made of 80 levels with a cool horror atmosphere and a lot of originality.

Seven claps out of ten.

reviewText:
This experience will stay with you forever.

As the blurb suggests, Dark Echo sees you utilising sound to enable you to visualise your surroundings. The sounds you create ricochet around you in the form of coloured lines. You goal, naturally, is to escape the darkness, and escape whatever the hell is in it with you.

I found the gameplay enjoyable overall. The difficulty curve is just right - with a bit of persistence and some careful planning, navigating the darkness can be fun, sometimes scary, but achieveable for everyone. Controls consist of basic movement, throwing stones for decoys, clapping your hands (with various degrees of strength, depending how long you hold the button down for), and stealth. And you'll probably be using stealth quite a bit.

You have your white, regular soundwaves for normal surfaces, yellow for switches. But the real fun starts with blue and red soundwaves. Blue is for water, which is something you'll want to avoid on account of it being so noisy, and red you'll also want to avoid, on account of it being able to kill you at a touch.

And oh my god, if you die. The first time I died I almost leapt a full metre out of my chair. The death scream is perfect. In fact, most all the sounds are done to perfection. From your echoing footsteps to the sound your hands clapping together, it is very well done.

Dark Echo really is a worthy addition to any gamer's library. While it lacks a story of any sort, it does do everything else right, giving us a new take on fear, exploration and stealth. Even if it doesn't sound like fun to you (I don't imagine how this could be) get this game and give it a try. Price alone is reason enough.

reviewText:
First off, the game is only $3, so what do you have to lose.
My kids saw this game in my steam library after I bought it and were really interested in the game due to the simplistic and crisp graphics. I booted it up and played the first several levels during the daytime without headphones with my kids.
It had an interesting game mechanic and there is no blood, no violence, only minimalist graphics and fantastic audio. I had a good time playing with the kids, learning the different strategies and new game mechanics in each level.
Then ... then I played it again at night with headphones, this game can be intense Wow, can it be intense.
Definitely a great little horror title.

reviewText:
Seeing the game's trailer, screenshots and description caught my interest and I grabbed this game quite cheap during sales. I found this game to be a somewhat unique and atmospheric in-the-dark visualized-sound puzzle type of game.

The first few levels are easy enough (which I guess they are more like introductory or tutorial type of levels), but a few levels in I soon discovered that there were lurking dangers in the dark (some which would chase me) and the game suddenly became a lot more challenging (and even a bit scary at times).

The graphics are simplistic, but suit this type of game well as what you see is sound feedback" from your surroundings. It's suggested to wear headphones to be more immersed in the atmosphere and better hear the sounds or in what direction something might be at.

Overall I do like what I've played of this game so far and I could recommend it to anyone who may be considering getting it. Cheers! :)

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=590515749"

reviewText:
February 7, 2016
Dark Echo is a mobile game with unique minimal graphics, which some people view artistically. In actuality, the game is a top-down casual adventure game with sound built into the graphics. Yes, it's unique, but the game quickly runs out of material and becomes irritating to finish. The low price helps, but it's not a game I'll likely remember.

The core gameplay is to reach the exit, avoiding red traps and pushing yellow plates to open walls. Detecting objects requires sounds, so most of the time you will be sending out foot pings to map out rooms. The real gameplay opens up when enemies are introduced, and sounds become a risk of detection. In the best moments, Dark Echo is about outmaneuvering enemies and feeling smart about your moves.

In the worst moments, Dark Echo is about trial & error memorization of traps and enemies, since the optimal playstyle is to make no noise. Issues come up when the game throws in more enemies and more water, forcing you to drag groups further out of the way so you'll have more time to move. Enemy detection also shows issues, as detection is dependent on sound lines hitting enemies. Sound lines may be pretty consistent, but it would make more sense to be doppler waves for consistency. Rock tosses will generally miss at medium range, unless the rock hits a wall to amplify. Too much time is spent spamming rocks to move enemies just right, and waiting on the slow death animation.

Although the game has 80 levels, half of them are repeats with added difficulty. The survival horror concepts are lost with the flood of identical enemies and repeated deaths. The puzzle elements are minimal switches, and no real mental challenge outside memorization. The lack of tension and challenges leave the game feeling like a grind to finish, despite being short. It would take closer to 5+ hours to complete, and I left the game idle overnight. I suppose the game isn't too expensive, but I wasn't impressed or pleased by the second half. Sadly it's another artsy game that says nothing and puts style over substance.

reviewText:
Having bought this on a whim, I'm very pleased with my purchase. Playing it in a darkened room on a dreary night is a must to get the full experience but even without that it's still a neat little puzzle game.

I've had a fair few butt-clenching moments and only two instances where I got frustrated with the game. And that frustration limits itself to a couple of levels with moving walls. They're over quickly enough to not be an issue.

The game is short, so it doesn't overstay its welcome. To be honest, it could just as easily have been a free flash game; but I'm glad it isn't. The developer made a small piece of art here, and fully deserves whatever income the game generates. Which can't be much because it costs next to nothing.

Just buy it and give it a chance. I was pleasantly surprised and I'm willing to bet you will be too.

reviewText:
Minimilistic style, atmospheric horror game. This game was produced as an indie project and it was certainly well made. In this game you play a blind man lost somewhere, because of some reason and now he has to escape somehow because everything in this place is trying to murder him on as soon as the things in question. Everywhere there are things that are making spooky noices, fitting and actually creepy noices.
The gameplay is simple and easy to learn. You can only see be making sounds. Now, there were some interesting things done with this concept. you can only see hazards when you make sounds and many of those hazards will come to the source of the noice and straight out murder you. This forces you to think about almost every move you make in this game and creates tension, but if you ♥♥♥♥ up you're ♥♥♥♥ed. The sound design is incredible. No music at all, but every sound effect in this game helps to create this tension, which you can easely cut by breathing to loud.
Being a blind man really makes this entiry game really interesting. going back on what I said before, you know absolutely nothing about what is going one. 'Who am I?' 'WTF is that?' 'WTF was that?' 'Where the ♥♥♥♥ am I?' None of these questions will be answered. You your self will try and fill in the questions, this too will help make the entire game even more tens, if that's even possible.
It's is a pity that a while in the game it will be more trial and error than anything else. It won't be to frequent but you will notice it and you will be anoyed by the stupid, unnecessary deaths.
A good thing though is that, like a good game should be, the game gets gratually more difficult, excluding the trial and error levels.
This game is short, but it's cheap as hell. I fully recommend this tense as ♥♥♥♥ game.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwDi29VsPM4

Dark Echo doesn't just rely on soundwaves to build it's world, it uses the imagination of the player themselves to fill in the details of this deep, dank and deadly cave. Drawing you in with atmospheric sound design the world around you begins to take shape, from a drop of water rhythmically falling from the ceiling to the deadly monsters lurking around every corner. The controls feel very tight, every single foot step has a weight to it. As the levels go on the game remains fresh, introducing new concepts and challenges at a fair and even pace. If I had one complaint it's that the elements of horror don't feel frantic enough, running away from monsters feels more like a jog through the mall than a life or death situation. Perhaps this is because the game wishes to be more of a puzzler than survival horror. Still loved that loud DEATH SCREAM though! There really is nothing else like Dark Echo, highly recommended!

PROS
-strong atmosphere
-smooth difficulty curve
-extremely unique mechanics

CONS
-monster encounters could be more intense


DISCLAIMER: Review is based on approx. 1 hour of gameplay.

reviewText:
Dark Echo is a minimalistic exploration game. You are shrouded in darkness (or, for the second half of the game, in blinding light), and the only way for you to navigate through the levels is the echos of your footsteps (represented by colored lines which radiate out from where you’re standing). You have the ability to stomp your foot (making louder echoes), walk silently (to avoid alerting enemies to your presence), and throw stones (to make echoes in a remote location to lure enemies away).

The game is very simple; there are only a handful of mechanics. There are red enemies who move towards the last sound they were in range of earing, there are pits of water which slow you down and which make a lot of sound to move through, there are red areas that killed you if you moved into them, there were walls that would collapse when you made a loud sound (opening an area but also attracting enemies), and there were moving blocks which pushed you around.

Mostly, the game worked fairly decently; you are introduced to all the games’ mechanics gradually over the first half of the game, and navigate through a series of increasingly-difficult levels which force you to combine the mechanics in increasingly interesting ways.

While the game was mostly fairly solid, the moving blocks mechanic was probably the most frustrating; while it only appears in a handful of levels, the fact that the pushes are so difficult to see ahead of time is kind of frustrating. Eventually you figure out how they work (for a while, I just thought they were sloped areas that I was skidding down), but at times it felt like the game broke its own rules, such as one level where you had to navigate up little ramps that felt like they actually were sloped areas on the sides of the room.

Mostly, though, the game played very fairly, and even the frustrating levels were mostly quite short. After beating the game, you could hunt back through for treasures, or play through the “light” versions of the levels, where additional enemies were added in to make you play more carefully (as well as the layouts of some of the levels being changed to make them more difficult).

That said, the game is nothing super special; the gameplay isn’t really amazing, but it is decent enough. Ultimately, this is a sort of time-waster game – the sort of thing you’d play while chatting to someone or doing something else, sporadically playing it. It was originally a mobile game, and I suspect it is better suited to that platform simply because of its “play in short bursts” nature.

Still, it is okay, and if you’re looking for something to do between doing other things, it isn’t a bad choice, and goes to show that just because you don’t spend a whole lot on graphics doesn’t mean you can’t make a visually striking game. Just dont' expect it to be anything more than a distraction.

reviewText: It's easy to recommend this game to people who like puzzle games. It's surprisingly simple but effective mechanics, are used to their fullest; where it's not a matter of just rushing through a level, but in most cases you are using stealth. Where you are blind, and the only way you ascertain where you are is making or picking up sounds and echoes, represented by white (or black) light vectors. Sound is very minimalistic due to this, but adds to a somewhat unexpected atmosphere of slight horror. It's not a long game - I've spent about 2hrs and completed half of the levels, but it's also a fairly meagre price. As an added incentive, and a bit more replay value, there are hidden treasures" to find throughout the game

reviewText: At first I thought it was an interesting game with fresh concepts but after level 24 it started to get unfair. Level 25 introduces areas where you can't see the sound – which is pretty unrealistic and illogical. Beginning with level 27, you have to get killed a few times until you know the important stuff to complete the level. That isn't fair and, of course, isn't good game design as well. Disappointing. :-/

reviewText: I noticed that I've been far too kind to a lot of free-to-play artsy games recently, and I made a private promise that I'd go on a negative streak. I started with You Have to Win the Game"
date: and I suppose I might as well continue with Dark Echo.\n\nNow
recommended: I'm not recommending Dark Echo because I think it's a bad game. Dark Echo is an incredibly unique game with a stealth system all-it's-own. I just personally don't like it. But if you think the points I bring up won't bother you
hoursPlayed: then by all means buy this game.\n\nDark Echo is a stealth/horror game built around the idea that you're blind and have to rely on sound to guide your way through what I think is a castle with a ton of enigmatic monsters living inside it. The mechanics are very unique. If you choose to move quietly to not disturb the monsters
voteText: you won't be able to see far ahead and predict incoming obstacles. However
helpfulPercent: if you choose to be loud and find out what's ahead
votesHelpful: you might attract monsters who will eat you. But all this challenge and fright is pretty much diminished by the rocks. Once you get those all the levels that follow are an absolute piece of cake.\n\nDark Echo is certainly a horror game. It plays well with what you see as well as what you don't see
votesTotal: and uses sound to amp up the atmosphere and tension. But without a story
commentsCount: or building challenge to the monsters I didn't find myself sweating with terror at the end. I felt relieved
column17: but I know if the game put a little more oomph! into it
column18: Dark Echo could be so much better
column20: if this sounds appealing to you
column21: go nuts. Dark Echo is still an incredibly unique experience. But beyond the sometimes blandly simple levels and lack of story to really put things into context (and the added on padding where you simply play through all 40 levels again
column23: it just wasn't a game for me. But it might be the perfect game for someone else."

reviewText: Dark Echo is certainly an excellent take on the idea of sound-based perceptionin a video game, though there are some negative aspects i would like to cover later. I would recommend that you buy it, play it, and get a refund, for reasons you'll see later.\nFirst, though, the game is mostly an excellent experience. Suspense is created very effectively, as well as some mild horror. The game's mechanics are very polished and nice, with it's slightly randomized sound wave direction, so that no walk will be exactly the same; the sneak mechanice's effectiveness in water could be adjusted for more realism, but i understand that it's wave length is so expansive for the sake of the suspense and challenge; the enemies' speed is just enough to provide great suspense, and the large enemy is certainly a great fear that the game always gives you a chance to avoid (or rather, run from). The simple style of the game provides a nice ambiance, so that if you stop making sound for even a few seconds, you will be lost until you make sound again, likely putting you in danger.\nNow on to negative points. First off, the game is NOT worth $2.99, since there is simply not enought content, in my opinion, to be priced that high. $1.49 maximum. The game is inconsistent in the later levels(30-40 mainly),in that it throw's away" the machanics it has taught you from the beginning. one level leaves you stranded in a widely expansive empty map
date: following sounds of dripping water just beyond your view. no other place in the game requires you to listen for direction or guidance. another level leaves you in a room where you must obeserve the pattern of moving landscape to find an opening to stop the motion at a specific time which will allow you to progress (harder than it sounds). My biggest point
voteText: in which you are placed in a large landscape of rough-walled caves where you must walk around blindly until you randomly find the exit
helpfulPercent: with other paths leading you to dead ends with enemies.\nThe game also has a "light mode"
votesHelpful: which is simply a negative print of the game with enemies added to nearly every room
commentsCount: or some rooms' layout changed. The game's achievements also consist of "beat normal mode"
column17: and "collect every secret". The game is good
column18: but mostly due to the extravagant price and lack of both general content and replay value
column19: i'll put it this way:\nI should have my refund soon."

Interesting basic concept of not able to see and have to rely on hearing to know your surroundings, while at the sametime not have enemies hear you. Hopefully this concept can expand further.

$3 is a good price for it, but could use a bit more content.

reviewText:
First playthrough time: 7 hours

Major Pros:
Excellent minimalist art style with a great use of colors
Good sound effects set mood and keep the player on edge (but aren't necessary for the game if they creep you out!)

Minor Pros:
The second half of the game, the light world, lets the player replay the same level layouts with new traps, solutions, and more (and faster) monsters
Excellent level design allows players to learn what to do on their own without explanation and level names give hints

Major Cons:
Angles to aim your character at in order to effectively throw rocks are limited to the 8 points of a compass

Minor Cons:
Will leave you terrified of orb shaped patterns of red lines which others will not understand
You will also learn to hate water
I think I fell" out of a level once or twice due to a moving block glitching me through a wall

I'm a sucker for a good art style and minimalist art styles like the one in Dark Echo with their high contrast and bright colors really appeal to me. Combine that with a unique puzzle experience that gives my mental visualization abilities a stretch and cheap price tag and I snagged this thing the day it came out. The following 7 hours of gameplay left my heart beating a little faster as I snuck
recommended: and bolted my way for the exit. I found all the levels to be interesting and fun except that one level at the end with too many moving parts where I died a lot and if you've played you know what I'm talking about. My biggest complaint about the game was just that your character is limited to only facing 8 different directions which makes creating effective distractions at the right place a little difficult sometimes. Given the simplicity of the controls however
hoursPlayed: the 8 direction limit seems appropriate. Overall I loved the game and hope to see many more like it in the future."

reviewText: Okay so lets be honest. This type of game is somewhat unique but isn't an original idea. It has been done before but not in this atmospheric horror fashion. Frankly I didn't feel the atmosphere that everyone talked about in the reviews. It was more annoying than anything. The game is trying to challenge you with certain aspects but it just ends up being boring (when you get to the stealth portions of the game you'll see what I mean).\nThe horror factor isn't all that great either. The reason other indie horror games (Take FNAF for example) are actually scary is because they always keep you on your toes. You always know that there's a monster right outside your door and you have .25 seconds to react. In this game you only feel annoyed by the enemies; like their purpose is just to distract you from your goal, rather than trying to eat you.\nThis game was a nice concept, the sound of footsteps to show paths combined with atmospheric horror, but it just didn't seem to live up to its potential. Now I feel like I've bought a game just for the achievements or collectibles, and that isn't how its supposed to be.

Cool game for the price.  With a good pair of headphones this games actually gets freaky for its simplicity.  A puzzle/maze game in the darkness of a cave system. The only way around is by walking or swimming lead only by your footprints and the sound waves you create. Creatures growl and snarl, trap doors, pools of water and flies whizzing around are some noises you'll hear.  Might get frustrating having to use trial and error as a means to get out.  Cool game.

A limited supply of rocks you can throw might also have tempered my use of them and made the game more challenging.

Dark Echo is a short but sweet horror game, with a twist. Its feature of using noise to determine where you are in the dark levels and when you should avoid monsters is most of its selling point, but it's still really good. Well worth the $3 for a few hours worth of gameplay. Depending on how stealthy or how much sneaking you want to do, some of the jumpscares might get you.

Minimal graphics, but chock full of atmosphere and intriguing concepts. Although you cannot see much the sound effects, the ambiance, the danger even, it all adds to a spectacular amount of immersion. At first it may seem difficult to get a grasp of your abilities to navigate the puzzles and mazes, but the game does a great job teaching you without explaining too much and eases the players flawlessly into the harder challenges. And with the affordable price (which I do feel may be underselling just a little) this is a perfect addition to any ambitious gamer's collection.

Dark Echo is a 2D game, that basically consists in finding a way through a world in which you can only trust your ears. Your steps make noise and the noisewaves show you your surroundings, but can also lure monsters to your position. The game can get really hard at some points and when you complete it, you unlock the light mode which is basically the same game but in way harder. In this mode you will have to be way more strategic and a fast thinker. Throughout the game, there are 15 hidden treasures that unlock an achievment when you find them all.\n\nAll in all, Dark Echo is a simple made, but challenging 2D game with 3 achievments that are easy to get in 3 hours of gameplay, but are still very satisfying. I definitely recommend this game to fans of the genre or people searching for a challenging and cheap game for their spare time.

This game has an excellent idea behind it.

I haven't necessarily seen this type of game before, so I would say that it does have some originality. I'm sure there's someone out there who doubts its originality, or has seen it before, but I'm not one of those people.

With that being said, I enjoyed the game for the time that I played it. I got all the way through the darkness, but I didn't go further than that. I think that at some point I will go back through and do the light levels, because I'm sure that there's something I might have missed.


Meat of the reviewI don't necessarily go by a rating system whenever I review games. I consider: Is it reasonably priced for the level of enjoyment I got out of the gameplay? Does it have a unique quality about it that other games don't have? Will I ever be able to go back and replay the game?

Those are three questions that I consider whenever I'm playing a game. Those are three fairly important questions to me as well.

First question: With a price tag of $2.99, it is very affordable. Not only that, but I was riveted to the game and I was determined on finishing all of the levels, I won't spoil how many. If you want to know here's the number:  30  Which I thought was a great amount of levels, and the variability of the levels was incredible. Not only is the game innovative, but the level design is complex and dynamic. The levels challenged my awareness and problem solving.  Of course, I think it is very reasonably priced for the level of enjoyment I got out of it.

Second question: Dark Echo is a game where  you are blind  and the object of the game is to find the exit using  your sense of hearing.  I found the game fascinating for this reason. This quality of the game gave the title of the game some depth. I thought that the nature of the game stuck to its title. The game is definitely unique in the respect of bringing gameplay to the table that hasn't been recycled over and over again.

Third question: As far as replayability is concerned, I'm going with that I'm not sure if it does have replayability. For me I didn't necessarily play this game for very long, but for the amount of time I played it I think it justified the price tag. But the light levels are something that are worth looking into for people who are potentially looking at this game and aren't necessarily sure about it.

VerdictOverall I think that the game is worth at least looking into. In all of my reviews, I tell everyone who gets this far to have a look at it. Don't take what I have to say and just go out and buy it. You should go look up videos, or look up other reviews. You and I might not have the same tastes as far as games are concerned. Enjoy Dark Echo!

However, i guarantee you that you will enjoy yourself every single second of it.  I recommend this game 100%.\n\n

This isn't the full on creepfest I was expecting but it's still a bloody good game for £1.99.

The atmosphere of the game is definitely tense as you can only see your surroundings as you move. The echoes of your footsteps bounce off the walls so you can see your environment,

The levels are quite short (I'm only 15 levels in and they're only a few seconds to a minute so far) so it's good if you don't have very long to sit down and really get involved in a game, but playing for longer in one sitting, will definitely build the tension and have you creeping towards the edge of your seat.

I'd deifnitely recommend this game and, at £1.99, it's an absolute bargain.

Creepy, intense, and chilling. A simplistic horror game that will have you jumping in your seat. The concept of using sound as a visual aid is amazing. Definitley recommend to everyone! 10/10

i played the original Ludum Dare version of this game several years ago and enjoyed it a lot, so it's very nice to see it become a full-fledged release.

as you might be able to infer, navigating using only sound and the visualizations it gives is a tense and foreboding experience. although there are occasionally things like the sound of water droplets to help give a better picture of your environment, most of the time you can only rely on your footsteps to see what is around you, not knowing if there's something deadly silently lurking around the corner waiting to pounce.

of course, since i actually like to mess around in horror games, one of my favorite things to do is lure baddies with a large stomp and then tiptoe a few feet away and watch them give up as soon as they reach the source. they lose interest immediately and it's kind of hilarious.

another little detail i enjoy is that there are different footstep noises; you might be walking on stone for a while but one corridor later you'll be walking on dirt or grass. it really adds a nice touch to each area, since you can kind of infer what your surroundings are even though you never actually see them.

overall this game is Outta Sight" and if you don't believe me you should "See It For Yourself" because it's "A Hidden Gem" and it's pretty cheap too."
This game feels claustrophobic and terrifying - as intended, I'm sure. The puzzles aren't too difficult, but on top of the game's unique game mechanics, they become a lot more challenging.

Dark Echo is a short but sweet horror game, with a twist. Its feature of using noise to determine where you are in the dark levels and when you should avoid monsters is most of its selling point, but it's still really good. Well worth the $3 for a few hours worth of gameplay. Depending on how stealthy or how much sneaking you want to do, some of the jumpscares might get you.

reviewText: Regardless of the fact that I rather use the visuals rather than the sounds inn order to find my way this game is well done.\nKept me playing for nearly 2 hours in the first sitting. With other games I often lose my interest after half an hour. Well done minimalism that made me jump two times up to level 36. Some levels are like thief - only in 2D, reduced visuals and from a bird´s view. ...but why Z and not R? Fingerstretcher
Sweet Game. Surprising amount of levels, and really cool mechanics that are introduced throughout.\ndefinately worth the small price.\nIf it is on sale dont even question, just buy it.

It's a little mundane at points, but you get whats advertised.\n\nIt is DEFINATLEY not a horror game and much better classified as a puzzle game, but if you're into those it should keep you entertained.

Dark Echo has a great novel concept and a nice art style. Unfortunately, it does not fulfill its promise. I liked the beginning a lot, but becomes boring and tedious later on. I played the dark levels on Android and some of the white levels on PC, so I can compare both versions.

There are 3 main mechanics in the game (tapping, sneaking, throwing rocks). They are interesting early on, but no other concept is introduced later on, and there are no new mechanics introduced in the later levels (maybe except moving objects). The game seems to be a half-finished, with so many interested things that could have been introduced in the game, but weren't.

The number of levels is low. There are 40 dark levels, which you can finished in a couple of hours, and 40 white levels, which are the same levels with many more (and bigger and faster) enemies, and a very uncomfortable full-white background. There's not much motivation to play the white levels. Also, one wonders why there aren't more unique levels than 40. Given that designing new levels seems extremely easy, their current number feels more like a demo than a regular game.

The controls are unfortunately very poorly implemented. On touch devices, it's very hard to sneak, and sometimes you perform a regular step instead of sneaking, which means instadeath in later (white) levels. Imprecise controls on touch devices was a reason why I switched to PC version for later levels. On the other hand, on touch devices you can very easily throw rocks into arbitrary direction, and it's very easy to precisely position your enemy. Mind-bogglingly, you can't do that on PC. Even though it would be very obvious to use mouse cursor to throw rocks, you can't, and you can only throw to 8 basic directions using the keyboard. Also, you always need to face the direction you're throwing into, so you can't distract an enemy by throwing a rock to the side when running away, as it would be natural. With gamepad, you can throw to arbitrary directions, but as is usual with a gamepad stick, aiming is hard. So while PC version makes it easier to move, it makes it harder to aim compared to touch devices. In none of the versions you can control your character well. Controls were my number 1 frustration when playing later levels. The ideal controls seem so obvious - left mouse click to walk, shift to sneak, space to tap, right mouse click to throw to the exact direction. Yet it is not there.

Hopefully someone will use this concept and make a great with it, with more interesting levels, more enemy types, more interactive and environment objects (I can imagine e.g. terrain elevation changing sound waves reflection), better controls, more fun.

I have never clapped so hard to a game...\n\nbut seriously, rarely a single game can captivate my attention in this times and Dark Echo did it. What I like most is that imagination does what it should, so there is much more in it than in 80% of 3D survival horrors. It is simple, but well made and some levels are hard to sneak, but it always seems to be fair.

reviewText: I like the originality and tone of the game.  I like how simple it is without being easy.  But, I would say the game was a little too short.  It could've used a little bit more variety with enemies, and the difficulty sort of caps out".  What I mean by that is there's only so much the developers can do to make the game harder without it being tedious or impossible.  There are many scenes that *seem* like they'd be hard
date: but I know there is no other way out
recommended: which makes the obstacles less challenging than they appear to be."

reviewText: Brilliant conceptual exploration and adequate theming. People who say the game was too small to be worth money don't know what it's like to be a struggling artist. I do, and I'm happy to pay to play this really clever idea.
